<A NAME="eolPage25"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D262254D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="10%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<A NAME="D262254D10K_HTM_ROM110360_18">
</A>
	Item&nbsp;7.
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations (MD&amp;A) (Note references are to the Notes to the Consolidated Financial
	Statements included in Item&nbsp;8, below.)
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-6PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	OVERVIEW
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-6PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Unitil is a public utility holding company headquartered in Hampton, New Hampshire. Unitil is subject to regulation as a holding company
	system by the FERC under the Energy Policy Act of 2005.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Unitil&#146;s principal business is the local distribution of electricity and natural gas to approximately 184,200 customers throughout its service territory in the states of New Hampshire, Massachusetts
	and Maine. Unitil is the parent company of three wholly-owned distribution utilities:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-6PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="5%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	i)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Unitil Energy, which provides electric service in the southeastern seacoast and state capital regions of New Hampshire;
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-6PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="5%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	ii)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Fitchburg, which provides both electric and natural gas service in the greater Fitchburg area of north central Massachusetts; and
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-6PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="5%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	iii)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Northern Utilities, which provides natural gas service in southeastern New Hampshire and portions of southern and central Maine, including the city of Portland and the
	Lewiston-Auburn area.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Unitil
	Energy, Fitchburg and Northern Utilities are collectively referred to as the &#147;distribution utilities.&#148; Together, the distribution utilities serve approximately 104,300 electric customers and 79,900 natural gas customers in their service
	territory.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In addition, Unitil is the parent
	company of Granite State, a natural gas transmission pipeline, regulated by the FERC, operating 86 miles of underground gas transmission pipeline primarily located in Maine and New Hampshire. Granite State provides Northern Utilities with
	interconnection to three major natural gas pipelines and access to North American pipeline supplies.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The distribution utilities are local &#147;pipes and wires&#148; operating companies, and Unitil had an investment in Net Utility Plant of
	$883.4&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2016. Unitil&#146;s total revenue was $383.4&nbsp;million in 2016, which includes revenue to recover the approved cost of purchased electricity and natural gas in rates on a fully reconciling basis. As a
	result of this reconciling rate structure, the Company&#146;s earnings are not affected by changes in the cost of purchased electricity and natural gas. Earnings from Unitil&#146;s utility operations are derived from the return on investment in the
	three distribution utilities and Granite State.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Unitil also conducts
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-regulated
</FONT>
	operations principally through Usource, which is wholly-owned
	by Unitil Resources. Usource provides energy brokering and advisory services to a national client base of large commercial and industrial customers. Usource&#146;s total revenues were $6.1&nbsp;million in 2016. The Company&#146;s other subsidiaries
	include Unitil Service, which provides, at cost, a variety of administrative and professional services to Unitil&#146;s affiliated companies, and Unitil Realty, which owns and manages Unitil&#146;s corporate office building and property located in
	Hampton, New Hampshire. Unitil&#146;s consolidated net income includes the earnings of the holding company and these subsidiaries.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Regulation
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-6PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Unitil is subject to comprehensive regulation by federal and state regulatory authorities. Unitil and its subsidiaries are subject to
	regulation as a holding company system by the FERC under the Energy Policy Act of 2005 with regard to certain bookkeeping, accounting and reporting requirements. Unitil&#146;s utility operations related to wholesale and interstate energy business
	activities are also regulated by the FERC. Unitil&#146;s distribution utilities are subject to regulation by the applicable state public utility commissions, with regard to their rates, issuance of securities and other accounting and operational
	matters: Unitil Energy is subject to regulation by the NHPUC; Fitchburg is subject to regulation by the MDPU; and Northern Utilities is regulated by the NHPUC and MPUC. Granite State, Unitil&#146;s interstate natural gas transmission pipeline, is
	subject to regulation by the FERC with regard to its rates and operations. Because Unitil&#146;s primary operations are subject to rate regulation, the regulatory treatment of various matters could significantly affect the Company&#146;s operations
	and financial position.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	23
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage26"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D262254D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Unitil&#146;s distribution utilities deliver electricity and/or natural gas to all customers
	in their service territory, at rates established under traditional cost of service regulation. Under this regulatory structure, Unitil&#146;s distribution utilities recover the cost of providing distribution service to their customers based on a
	historical test year, and earn a return on their capital investment in utility assets. In addition, the Company&#146;s distribution utilities and its natural gas transmission pipeline company may also recover certain base rate costs, including
	capital project spending and enhanced reliability and vegetation management programs, through annual step adjustments and cost tracker rate mechanisms.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Most of Unitil&#146;s customers have the opportunity to purchase their electricity or natural gas supplies from third-party energy
	suppliers. Many of Unitil&#146;s distribution utilities&#146; largest C&amp;I customers purchase their electricity or gas supply from third party suppliers, while most small C&amp;I customers, as well residential customers, purchase their
	electricity or gas supply from the distribution utilities under regulated rates and tariffs. Unitil&#146;s distribution utilities purchase electricity or natural gas from unaffiliated wholesale energy suppliers and recover the actual approved costs
	of these supplies on a pass-through basis, through reconciling rate mechanisms that are periodically adjusted.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Also see
<I>
	Regulatory Matters
</I>
	shown below and Note 8 (Commitments and Contingencies) to the accompanying Consolidated Financial
	Statements for additional information on rates and regulation.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Fitchburg is subject to revenue decoupling. Revenue decoupling is the term given to the elimination of the dependency of a utility&#146;s distribution revenue on the volume of electricity or natural gas
	sales. The difference between distribution revenue amounts billed to customers and the targeted revenue decoupling amounts is recognized as an increase or a decrease in Accrued Revenue which forms the basis for resetting rates for future cash
	recoveries from, or credits to, customers. These revenue decoupling targets may be adjusted as a result of rate cases that the Company files with the MDPU. The Company estimates that revenue decoupling applies to approximately 27% and 11% of
	Unitil&#146;s total annual electric and natural gas sales volumes, respectively.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_RESULTS_OF_OPERATIONS>
<A NAME="FIS_RESULTS_OF_OPERATIONS"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-6PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The following discussion of the Company&#146;s financial condition and results of operations should be read in conjunction with the accompanying Consolidated Financial Statements and the accompanying
	Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in Part II, Item&nbsp;8 of this report.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Company&#146;s results of operations are expected to reflect the seasonal nature of the natural gas business. Annual gas revenues are substantially realized during the colder weather seasons of the
	year as a result of higher sales of natural gas used for heating related purposes. Accordingly, the results of operations are historically most favorable in the first and fourth quarters. Fluctuations in seasonal weather conditions may have a
	significant effect on the result of operations. Sales of electricity are generally less sensitive to weather than natural gas sales, but may also be affected by the weather conditions and the temperature in both the winter and summer seasons. Also,
	as a result of recent rate cases, the Company&#146;s natural gas sales margins are derived from a higher percentage of fixed billing components, including customer charges. Therefore, natural gas revenues and margin will be less affected by the
	seasonal nature of the natural gas business. In addition, as discussed above, approximately 27% and 11% of the Company&#146;s total annual electric and natural gas sales volumes, respectively, are decoupled and changes in sales to existing customers
	do not affect sales margin on decoupled sales volumes.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Net
	Income and EPS Overview
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-6PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	2016 Compared
	to 2015
</I>
</B>
	&#151;The Company&#146;s Net Income was $27.1&nbsp;million, or $1.94 per share, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, a 3.0% increase of $0.8&nbsp;million in Net Income, and $0.05 per share, compared to 2015. The Company&#146;s
	earnings for 2016 were driven by increases in natural gas and electric sales margins and lower utility operating costs.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Natural gas sales margin was $103.6&nbsp;million in the twelve months ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, resulting in an increase of
	$1.7&nbsp;million compared to 2015. Gas sales margin in the twelve month period was positively affected by higher natural gas distribution rates and customer growth, partially offset by the
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	24
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage27"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D262254D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	negative impact of warmer winter weather on sales in the beginning of 2016. Based on weather data collected in the Company&#146;s natural gas service areas, there were 8% fewer Heating Degree
	Days (HDD) in 2016 compared to 2015. The Company estimates that the warmer winter weather in 2016 negatively impacted gas sales margins by approximately $3.3&nbsp;million, or $0.15 per share.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Electric sales margin was $88.1&nbsp;million in the twelve months ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, resulting in an
	increase of $2.6&nbsp;million compared to 2015. Electric sales margins in 2016 were positively affected by customer growth, higher electric distribution rates and the favorable effect of above normal summer temperatures.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Total Operation&nbsp;&amp; Maintenance (O&amp;M) expenses
	decreased $0.8&nbsp;million in 2016 compared to 2015, reflects lower utility operating costs of $2.0&nbsp;million, including lower electric and gas distribution system maintenance costs of $1.3&nbsp;million and lower bad debt expenses of
	$0.7&nbsp;million, and lower outside service professional fees of $0.9&nbsp;million, partially offset by higher compensation and benefit costs of $2.1&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Depreciation and Amortization expense increased
	$0.9&nbsp;million in 2016 compared to 2015, reflecting higher depreciation of $1.8&nbsp;million on normal utility plant assets in service, partially offset by lower amortization of $0.9&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Taxes Other Than Income Taxes increased $1.9&nbsp;million in
	2016 compared to 2015, primarily reflecting higher local property taxes on higher levels of utility plant assets in service.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Interest Expense, net increased $0.6&nbsp;million in 2016 compared to 2015 reflecting higher levels of short-term debt and lower net
	interest income on regulatory assets.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Other
	Expense (Income), net changed from income of $0.5&nbsp;million in 2015 to an expense of $0.3&nbsp;million in 2016. This change was the result of the recognition of a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-tax
</FONT>
	gain of $0.9&nbsp;million in the
	fourth quarter of 2015 on the sale of its former Distribution Operations Center facility in Portland, Maine.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Usource, the Company&#146;s
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-regulated
</FONT>
	energy brokering business, recorded revenues of
	$6.1&nbsp;million in 2016, essentially on par with 2015. Usource&#146;s revenues are primarily derived from fees billed to suppliers as customers take delivery of energy from these suppliers under term contracts brokered by Usource.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Income Taxes in 2016 were essentially unchanged compared to
	2015, reflecting higher
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-tax
</FONT>
	earnings in 2016 and higher federal and state tax credits recognized in 2016.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In 2016, Unitil&#146;s annual common dividend was $1.42 per share, representing an unbroken record of quarterly dividend payments since
	trading began in Unitil&#146;s common stock. At its January 2017 meeting, the Unitil Corporation Board of Directors declared a quarterly dividend on the Company&#146;s common stock of $0.36 per share, an increase of $0.005 per share on a quarterly
	basis, resulting in an increase in the effective annual dividend rate to $1.44 per share from $1.42 per share.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	2015 Compared to 2014
</I>
</B>
	&#151;The Company&#146;s Net Income was $26.3&nbsp;million, or $1.89 per share, for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2015, an increase of $1.6&nbsp;million, or $0.10 per share, compared to 2014. The Company&#146;s earnings for 2015 were driven by increases in natural gas and electric sales margins partially offset by higher utility operating
	expenses.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	A more detailed discussion of the
	Company&#146;s 2016 and 2015 results of operations and a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	year-to-year
</FONT>
</FONT>
	comparison of changes in financial position are presented below.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Gas Sales, Revenues and Margin
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-6PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Therm Sales
</I>
</B>
	&#151;Unitil&#146;s total therm
	sales of natural gas decreased 6.2% in 2016 compared to 2015. Sales to residential and C&amp;I customers decreased 10.2% and 5.2%, respectively, in 2016 compared to 2015. The decrease in gas therm sales in the Company&#146;s service areas was driven
	by warmer winter weather in the first quarter of 2016 compared to 2015, partially offset by customer growth. Based on weather data collected in the Company&#146;s natural gas service areas, there were 8% fewer HDD in 2016 compared to 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	25
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage28"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D262254D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Company estimates that weather-normalized gas therm sales, excluding decoupled sales, were up 1.2% in 2016 compared to 2015. This growth was led by a year over year increase of 3.3% in gas
	therm sales to large industrial customers. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016 the number of total natural gas customers served has increased by 1,189 in the last twelve months. As discussed above, sales margin derived from decoupled unit sales
	(representing approximately 11% of total annual therm sales volume) is not sensitive to changes in gas therm sales.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Unitil&#146;s total therm sales of natural gas increased 1.5% in 2015 compared to 2014. The impact of growth in the number of customers
	year over year was partially offset by warmer winter weather in 2015 compared to the prior year. The average number of natural gas customers served increased by 1.8% in 2015 compared to the prior year. For the full year, based on weather data
	collected in the Company&#146;s service areas, there were 2.3% fewer Heating Degree Days in 2015 compared to 2014. The Company estimates that weather-normalized gas therm sales, excluding decoupled sales, were up 4% in 2015 compared to 2014, led by
	a year over year increase of eight percent in gas therm sales to large C&amp;I customers.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The following table details total therm sales for the last three years, by major customer class:
</FONT>
</P>

	Therms

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Company analyzes
	operating results using Gas Sales Margin, a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-GAAP
</FONT>
	measure. Gas Sales Margin is calculated as Total Gas Operating Revenue less Cost of Gas Sales. The Company believes Gas Sales Margin is an important measure
	to analyze profitability because the approved cost of sales are tracked and reconciled to costs that are passed through directly to customers, resulting in an equal and offsetting amount reflected in Total Gas Operating Revenue. Sales margin can be
	reconciled to Operating Income, a GAAP measure, by including Operation and Maintenance, Depreciation and Amortization and Taxes Other Than Income Taxes for each segment in the analysis.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Natural gas sales margin was $103.6&nbsp;million in 2016, resulting in an increase of $1.7&nbsp;million
	compared to 2015. Gas sales margin in 2016 was positively affected by $3.7&nbsp;million in higher natural gas distribution rates and customer growth of $1.3&nbsp;million, partially offset by the negative impact of warmer winter weather in 2016 of
	$3.3&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The decrease in Total Gas
	Operating Revenues of $21.4&nbsp;million, or 10.6%, in 2016 compared to 2015 reflects lower natural gas sales volumes and lower cost of gas sales, which are tracked and reconciled costs that are passed through directly to customers.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	26
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage29"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D262254D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Natural gas sales margin was $101.9&nbsp;million in 2015, resulting in an increase of
	$4.5&nbsp;million compared to 2014. Approximately $3.4&nbsp;million of the increase reflects higher natural gas distribution rates and $1.1&nbsp;million of the increase reflects higher sales volumes related to customer growth, net of the impact of
	warmer winter weather in 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The increase in
	Total Gas Operating Revenues of $1.2&nbsp;million, or 0.6%, in 2015 compared to 2014 reflects higher gas base rates and sales volumes, partially offset by lower costs of gas sales, which are tracked and reconciled to costs that are passed through
	directly to customers.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Electric Sales, Revenues and Margin
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-6PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Kilowatt-hour
	Sales
</I>
</B>
	&#151;Unitil&#146;s total electric kWh sales decreased 2.3% in 2016 compared to 2015. Sales to residential customers and C&amp;I customers decreased 3.0% and 1.9%, respectively, in 2016 compared to 2015, reflecting warmer winter in 2016
	compared to 2015, partially offset by warmer summer weather in 2016. Based on weather data collected in the Company&#146;s electric service areas, there were 12% more Cooling Degree Days in 2016 compared to 2015. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the
	number of total electric customers served has increased by 1,003 in the last twelve months. As discussed above, sales margins derived from revenue decoupled unit sales (representing approximately 27% of total annual sales volume) are not sensitive
	to changes in kWh sales.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Unitil&#146;s total
	electric kWh sales decreased 0.7% in 2015 compared to 2014. Sales to residential customers decreased 2.4% in 2015 compared to 2014, reflecting a decrease in average use per customer. Sales to C&amp;I customers increased 0.5% in 2015 compared to
	2014, reflecting the addition of new customers.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The following table details total kWh sales for the last three years by major customer class:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_14"></A>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="58%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="2%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="2%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="2%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="2%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>

<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="2%">
</TD>

</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="2%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Company analyzes
	operating results using Electric Sales Margin, a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-GAAP
</FONT>
	measure. Electric Sales Margin is calculated as Total Electric Operating Revenues less Cost of Electric Sales. The Company believes Electric Sales
	Margin is an important measure to analyze profitability because the approved cost of sales are tracked and reconciled to costs that are passed through directly to customers resulting in an equal and offsetting amount reflected in Total Electric
	Operating Revenues. Sales margin can be reconciled to Operating Income, a GAAP measure, by including Operation and Maintenance, Depreciation and Amortization and Taxes Other Than Income Taxes for each segment in the analysis.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	27
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage30"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D262254D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Electric sales margin was $88.1&nbsp;million in 2016, resulting in an increase of
	$2.6&nbsp;million compared to 2015. Electric sales margin in 2016 was positively affected by $3.1&nbsp;million in higher electric distribution rates and the positive impact of $1.2&nbsp;million resulting from warmer summer weather in 2016, partially
	offset by the negative impact of warmer winter weather of $1.7&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The decrease in Total Electric Operating Revenue of $21.9&nbsp;million, or 10.0%, in 2016 compared to 2015 reflects lower electric sales volumes and lower cost of electric sales, which are tracked and
	reconciled to costs that are passed through directly to customers.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Electric sales margin was $85.5&nbsp;million in 2015, resulting in an increase of $4.7&nbsp;million compared to 2014. Higher electric distribution rates of $5.0&nbsp;million and the positive impact of
	$0.7&nbsp;million resulting from warmer summer weather in 2015 were partially offset by approximately $1.0&nbsp;million of lower electric sales margin, reflecting lower average usage in 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The decrease in Total Electric Operating Revenue of $0.7&nbsp;million, or 0.3%, in 2015 compared to 2014
	reflects lower costs of electric sales, which are tracked costs that are passed through directly to customers, partially offset by higher electric distribution rates.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Operating Revenue&#151;Other
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-6PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Total Other Operating Revenue is comprised of revenues from
	the Company&#146;s
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-regulated
</FONT>
	energy brokering business, Usource. Usource&#146;s revenues in 2016 were $6.1&nbsp;million, essentially on par with 2015. Usource&#146;s revenues in 2015 were
	$6.2&nbsp;million, an increase of $0.5&nbsp;million compared to 2014. As an energy broker and advisor, Usource assists business customers with the procurement and contracting for electricity and natural gas in competitive energy markets.
	Usource&#146;s revenues are primarily derived from fees billed to suppliers as customers take delivery of energy from these suppliers under term contracts brokered by Usource.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The following table details total Other Revenue for the last
	three years:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Operating Expenses
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-6PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Cost of Gas Sales
</B>
	&#151;Cost of Gas Sales includes the
	cost of natural gas purchased and manufactured to supply the Company&#146;s total gas supply requirements and spending on energy efficiency programs. Cost of Gas Sales decreased $23.1&nbsp;million, or 22.9%, in 2016 compared to 2015. This decrease
	reflects lower wholesale natural gas prices and lower sales of natural gas, partially offset by a decrease in the amount of natural gas purchased by customers directly from third-party suppliers. The Company reconciles and recovers the approved Cost
	of Gas Sales in its rates at cost on a pass through basis and therefore changes in approved expenses do not affect earnings.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In 2015, Cost of Gas Sales decreased $3.3&nbsp;million, or 3.2%, compared to 2014. This decrease reflects lower wholesale natural gas
	prices and decreased spending on energy efficiency programs, partially offset by higher sales of natural gas and a decrease in the amount of natural gas purchased by customers directly from third-party suppliers.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Cost of Electric Sales
</B>
	&#151;Cost of Electric Sales
	includes the cost of electric supply as well as other energy supply related restructuring costs, including power supply buyout costs, and spending on energy efficiency programs. Cost of Electric Sales decreased $24.5&nbsp;million, or 18.5%, in 2016
	compared to 2015. This decrease reflects lower electric kWh sales, lower wholesale electricity prices and an increase in the
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	28
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage31"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D262254D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	amount of electricity purchased by customers directly from third-party suppliers. The Company reconciles and recovers the approved Cost of Electric Sales in its rates at cost on a pass through
	basis and therefore changes in approved expenses do not affect earnings.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In 2015, Cost of Electric Sales decreased $5.4&nbsp;million, or 3.9%, compared to 2014. This decrease reflects lower electric kWh sales and an increase in the amount of electricity purchased by customers
	directly from third-party suppliers.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Operation
	and Maintenance
</B>
	&#151;O&amp;M expense includes electric and gas utility operating costs, and the operating costs of the Company&#146;s
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-regulated
</FONT>
	business activities. Total O&amp;M expenses decreased
	$0.8&nbsp;million, or 1.2%, in 2016 compared to 2015. The change in O&amp;M expenses reflects lower utility operating costs of $2.0&nbsp;million, including lower electric and gas distribution system maintenance costs of $1.3&nbsp;million and lower
	bad debt expenses of $0.7&nbsp;million, and lower outside service professional fees of $0.9&nbsp;million, partially offset by higher compensation and benefit costs of $2.1&nbsp;million. The savings achieved in utility operating costs in 2016 reflect
	maintenance costs at lower seasonal sales levels and the implementation of cost efficiency measures in 2016.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In 2015, total O&amp;M expenses increased $2.5&nbsp;million, or 3.9%, compared to 2014. The change in O&amp;M expenses reflects higher
	compensation and benefit costs of $3.5&nbsp;million partially offset by lower professional fees of $0.3&nbsp;million and lower all other utility O&amp;M costs, net of $0.7&nbsp;million. The decrease in utility operating costs includes
	$0.8&nbsp;million in lower electric and natural gas maintenance costs and higher all other utility operating costs, net of $0.1&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Depreciation and Amortization
</B>
	&#151;Depreciation and Amortization expense increased $0.9&nbsp;million, or 2.0%, in 2016 compared to
	2015, reflecting higher depreciation of $1.8&nbsp;million on normal utility plant assets in service, partially offset by lower amortization of $0.9&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In 2015, Depreciation and Amortization expense increased
	$3.6&nbsp;million, or 8.6%, compared to 2014, reflecting higher depreciation of $2.4&nbsp;million on normal utility plant assets in service, higher amortization of major storm restoration costs of $0.9&nbsp;million and an increase in all other
	amortization of $0.3&nbsp;million. The increase in major storm restoration cost amortization is currently recovered in electric rates and reflected in electric sales margin.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Taxes Other Than Income Taxes&#151;
</B>
	Taxes Other Than
	Income Taxes increased $1.9&nbsp;million, or 10.7%, in 2016 compared to 2015, primarily reflecting higher local property taxes on higher levels of utility plant assets in service.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In 2015, Taxes Other Than Income Taxes increased
	0.5&nbsp;million, or 2.9%, compared to 2014, reflecting higher local property taxes on higher levels of utility plant in service.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Interest Expense, net
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-6PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Interest expense is presented in the Consolidated Financial Statements net of interest income. Interest expense is mainly comprised of
	interest on long-term debt and short-term borrowings. Certain reconciling rate mechanisms used by the Company&#146;s distribution utilities give rise to regulatory assets (and regulatory liabilities) on which interest is calculated (See Note 5 to
	the accompanying Consolidated Financial Statements).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Interest Expense, net increased $0.6&nbsp;million, or 2.7%, in 2016 compared to 2015 reflecting higher levels of short-term debt and lower net interest income on regulatory assets.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In 2015, Interest Expense, net increased $1.0&nbsp;million,
	or 4.8%, compared to 2014 reflecting higher levels of long-term debt and higher interest expense on regulatory liabilities.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Other Expense (Income), net
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-6PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Other Expense (Income), net changed from income of $0.5&nbsp;million in 2015 to an expense of $0.3&nbsp;million in 2016. This change was
	the result of the recognition of a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-tax
</FONT>
	gain of $0.9&nbsp;million in the fourth quarter of 2015 on the sale of its former Distribution Operations Center facility in Portland, Maine.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	29
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage32"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D262254D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Other Expense (Income), net, changed from an expense of $0.4&nbsp;million in 2014 to income
	of $0.5&nbsp;million in 2015. This change was the result of the recognition of a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-tax
</FONT>
	gain of $0.9&nbsp;million in the fourth quarter of 2015 on the sale of property, discussed above.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Income Taxes
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-6PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Income Taxes in 2016 were essentially unchanged compared to
	2015 reflecting higher
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-tax
</FONT>
	earnings in 2016 and higher federal and state tax credits recognized in 2016 (See Note 9 to the accompanying Consolidated Financial Statements).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In 2015, Income Taxes increased $1.4&nbsp;million compared to
	2014 due to higher
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-tax
</FONT>
	earnings in 2015 compared to 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	LIQUIDITY, COMMITMENTS AND CAPITAL REQUIREMENTS
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-6PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Sources of Capital
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-6PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Unitil requires capital to fund utility plant additions, working capital and other utility expenditures recovered in subsequent periods through regulated rates. The capital necessary to meet these
	requirements is derived primarily from internally-generated funds, which consist of cash flows from operating activities. The Company initially supplements internally-generated funds through short-term bank borrowings, as needed, under its unsecured
	revolving Credit Facility. Periodically, the Company replaces portions of its short-term debt with long-term financings more closely matched to the long-term nature of its utility assets. Additionally, from time to time, the Company has accessed the
	public capital markets through public offerings of equity securities. The Company&#146;s utility operations are seasonal in nature and are therefore subject to seasonal fluctuations in cash flows. The amount, type and timing of any future financing
	will vary from year to year based on capital needs and maturity or redemptions of securities.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Company and its subsidiaries are individually and collectively members of the Unitil Cash Pool (the &#147;Cash Pool&#148;). The Cash Pool is the financing vehicle for
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	day-to-day
</FONT>
</FONT>
	cash borrowing and investing. The Cash Pool allows for an efficient exchange of cash among the Company and its subsidiaries. The interest rates charged to the subsidiaries for borrowing from the
	Cash Pool are based on actual interest costs from lenders under the Company&#146;s revolving Credit Facility. At December&nbsp;31, 2016 and December&nbsp;31, 2015, the Company and all of its subsidiaries were in compliance with the regulatory
	requirements to participate in the Cash Pool.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	On
	October&nbsp;4, 2013, the Company entered into an Amended and Restated Credit Agreement (as further amended, restated, amended and restated, modified or supplemented from time to time, the &#147;Credit Facility&#148;). The Credit Facility terminates
	October&nbsp;4, 2020 and provides for a borrowing limit of $120&nbsp;million which includes a $25&nbsp;million sublimit for the issuance of standby letters of credit. The Credit Facility provides Unitil with the ability to elect that borrowings
	under the Credit Facility bear interest under several options, including at a daily fluctuating rate of interest per annum equal to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	one-month
</FONT>
	London Interbank Offered Rate (LIBOR) plus 1.25%. Provided there is
	no event of default under the Credit Facility, the Company may on a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	one-time
</FONT>
	basis request an increase in the aggregate commitments under the Credit Facility by an aggregate additional amount of up to
	$30&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	30
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage33"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D262254D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Company utilizes the Credit Facility for cash management purposes related to its
	short-term operating activities. Total gross borrowings were $218.2&nbsp;million and $140.3&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 and December&nbsp;31, 2015, respectively. Total gross repayments were $178.3&nbsp;million and
	$127.6&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 and December&nbsp;31, 2015, respectively. In the third quarter of 2016, the Company issued a standby letter of credit for $1.1&nbsp;million. The following table details the borrowing
	limits, amounts outstanding and amounts available under the revolving Credit Facility as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and December&nbsp;31, 2015:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">

	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Credit Facility contains
	customary terms and conditions for credit facilities of this type, including affirmative and negative covenants. There are restrictions on, among other things, Unitil&#146;s and its subsidiaries&#146; ability to permit liens or incur indebtedness,
	and restrictions on Unitil&#146;s ability to merge or consolidate with another entity or change its line of business. The affirmative and negative covenants under the Credit Facility shall apply to Unitil until the Credit Facility terminates and all
	amounts borrowed under the Credit Facility are paid in full (or with respect to letters of credit, they are cash collateralized). The only financial covenant in the Credit Facility provides that Unitil&#146;s Funded Debt to Capitalization (as each
	term is defined in the Credit Facility) cannot exceed 65%, tested on a quarterly basis. At December&nbsp;31, 2016 and December&nbsp;31, 2015, the Company was in compliance with the covenants contained in the Credit Facility in effect on that date.
	(See also &#147;Credit Arrangements&#148; in Note 5.)
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Unitil Corporation and its utility subsidiaries, Fitchburg, Unitil Energy, Northern Utilities, and Granite State are currently rated &#147;BBB+&#148; by Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor&#146;s Ratings Services.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In April 2014, Unitil Service Corp. entered into
	a financing arrangement for various information systems and technology equipment. The financing arrangement is structured as a capital lease obligation. Final funding under this capital lease occurred on October&nbsp;30, 2015, resulting in total
	funding of $13.4&nbsp;million. The capital lease matures on September&nbsp;30, 2020. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, there are $2.6&nbsp;million of current and $7.8&nbsp;million of noncurrent obligations under this capital lease on the Company&#146;s
	Consolidated Balance Sheets.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The continued
	availability of various methods of financing, as well as the choice of a specific form of security for such financing, will depend on many factors, including, but not limited to: security market conditions; general economic climate; regulatory
	approvals; the ability to meet covenant issuance restrictions; the level of earnings, cash flows and financial position; and the competitive pricing offered by financing sources.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	31
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage34"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D262254D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Company and its subsidiaries have material energy supply commitments that are discussed
	in Note 7 to the accompanying Consolidated Financial Statements. Cash outlays for the purchase of electricity and natural gas to serve customers are subject to reconciling recovery through periodic changes in rates, with carrying charges on deferred
	balances. From year to year, there are likely to be timing differences associated with the cash recovery of such costs, creating under- or over-recovery situations at any point in time. Rate recovery mechanisms are typically designed to collect the
	under-recovered cash or refund the over-collected cash over subsequent periods of less than a year.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Company provides limited guarantees on certain energy and natural gas storage management contracts entered into by the distribution utilities. The Company&#146;s policy is to limit the duration of
	these guarantees. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, there were approximately $17.9&nbsp;million of guarantees outstanding and the longest term guarantee extends through August 2017.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Northern Utilities enters into asset management agreements
	under which Northern Utilities releases certain natural gas pipeline and storage assets, resells the natural gas storage inventory to an asset manager and subsequently repurchases the inventory over the course of the natural gas heating season at
	the same price at which it sold the natural gas inventory to the asset manager. There was $9.9&nbsp;million and $10.8&nbsp;million of natural gas storage inventory at December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, respectively, related to these asset management
	agreements. The amount of natural gas inventory released in December 2016, which was payable in January 2017, was $2.1&nbsp;million and recorded in Accounts Payable at December&nbsp;31, 2016. The amount of natural gas inventory released in December
	2015, which was payable in January 2016, was $0.6&nbsp;million and recorded in Accounts Payable at December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Company also guarantees the payment of principal, interest and other amounts payable on the notes issued by Unitil Realty and Granite
	State. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the principal amount outstanding for the 8% Unitil Realty notes was $0.4&nbsp;million, and the principal amount outstanding for the 7.15% Granite State notes was $6.7&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Benefit Plan Funding
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-6PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Company, along with its subsidiaries, made cash
	contributions to its Pension Plan in the amounts of $5.1&nbsp;million and $4.2&nbsp;million in 2016 and 2015, respectively. The Company, along with its subsidiaries, contributed $4.0&nbsp;million to Voluntary Employee Benefit Trusts (VEBTs) in each
	of 2016 and 2015. The Company, along with its subsidiaries, expects to continue to make contributions to its Pension Plan and the VEBTs in 2017 and future years at minimum required and discretionary funding levels consistent with the amounts
	recovered in the distribution utilities&#146; rates for these benefit plans. See Note 10 (Retirement Benefit Plans) to the accompanying Consolidated Financial Statements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Off-Balance
</FONT>
	Sheet Arrangements
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-6PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Company and its subsidiaries do not
	currently use, and are not dependent on the use of,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	off-balance
</FONT>
	sheet financing arrangements such as securitization of receivables or obtaining access to assets or cash through special purpose entities or
	variable interest entities. Unitil&#146;s subsidiaries conduct a portion of their operations in leased facilities and also lease some of their vehicles, machinery and office equipment under both capital and operating lease arrangements.
	Additionally, as of December&nbsp;31, 2016, there were approximately $17.9&nbsp;million of guarantees on certain energy and natural gas storage management contracts entered into by the distribution utilities outstanding and the longest term
	guarantee extends through August 2017. See Note 5 (Debt and Financing Arrangements) to the accompanying Consolidated Financial Statements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">

<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Unitil&#146;s utility operations, taken as a whole, are seasonal in nature and are therefore subject to seasonal fluctuations in cash
	flows. The tables below summarize the major sources and uses of cash (in millions) for 2016 and 2015.
</FONT>
</P>

<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	32

<A NAME="eolPage35"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D262254D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Cash Provided by Operating Activities
</B>
	&#151;Cash Provided by Operating Activities was
	$68.3&nbsp;million in 2016, a decrease of $46.8&nbsp;million compared to 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Cash flow from net income, adjusted for the total of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash
</FONT>
	charges to depreciation, amortization and deferred taxes, was $89.1&nbsp;million in 2016 compared to
	$83.9&nbsp;million in 2015, reflecting an increase of $5.2&nbsp;million. The increase in net income of $0.8&nbsp;million in 2016 compared to 2015 is primarily attributable to increases in natural gas and electric sales margins and customer growth.
	The increase in depreciation and amortization of $0.9&nbsp;million in 2016 compared to 2015 reflects higher utility depreciation from higher net utility plant in service. The increase in the deferred tax provision of $3.5&nbsp;million in 2016
	compared to 2015 is primarily a result of increased tax depreciation deductions and the Portland Natural Gas Transmission System (PNGTS) refund to customers (See Note 8).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Changes in working capital items resulted in a ($20.8)
	million use of cash in 2016 compared to a $18.5&nbsp;million source of cash in 2015, representing a decrease of $39.3&nbsp;million. Sources of cash from Regulatory Liabilities decreased $12.1&nbsp;million in 2016 compared to 2015, primarily driven
	by the current portion of the PNGTS to be refunded to customers (see Note 8). All other changes in working capital reflect normal variations from
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	year-to-year,
</FONT>
</FONT>
	including
	changes in underlying commodity prices.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Deferred
	Regulatory and Other Charges decreased $13.2&nbsp;million in 2016 compared to 2015, primarily driven by the long-term portion of the PNGTS refund. The change in Other, net in 2016 compared to 2015 was 0.5&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>

	Cash (Used in) Investing
	Activities
</B>
	&#151;Cash Used in Investing Activities was ($98.1) million in 2016 compared to ($103.9) million in 2015. The actual capital spending in both 2016 and 2015 is related to utility capital expenditures for electric and gas utility system
	additions. The Company&#146;s projected capital spending range for 2017 is $100&nbsp;million to $105&nbsp;million.

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Cash Provided by (Used in)
	Financing Activities
</B>
	&#151;Cash Provided by (Used in) Financing Activities was $26.9&nbsp;million in 2016 compared to ($10.9) million in 2015. The higher cash provided by financing activities in 2016 compared to 2015 is primarily attributable to
	the issuance of $30&nbsp;million of long-term debt in 2016. Other changes in financing activities in 2016 compared to 2015 are ($11.6) million greater repayment of long-term debt, ($8.9) million decrease in capital lease obligations, ($0.4) million
	greater dividends paid, offset by $27.2&nbsp;million greater proceeds of short-term debt and $1.5&nbsp;million of exchange gas financing.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	FINANCIAL COVENANTS AND RESTRICTIONS
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-6PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The agreements under which the Company and its subsidiaries issue long-term debt contain various covenants and restrictions. These
	agreements do not contain any covenants or restrictions pertaining to the maintenance of financial ratios or the issuance of short-term debt. These agreements do contain covenants relating to, among other things, the issuance of additional long-term
	debt, cross-default provisions, business combinations and covenants restricting the ability to (i)&nbsp;pay dividends, (ii)&nbsp;incur indebtedness and liens, (iii)&nbsp;merge or consolidate with another entity or (iv)&nbsp;sell, lease or otherwise
	dispose of all or substantially all assets. See Note 5 (Debt and Financing Arrangements) to the accompanying Consolidated Financial Statements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Unitil&#146;s Credit Facility contains customary terms and conditions for credit facilities of this type, including affirmative and
	negative covenants. There are restrictions on, among other things, Unitil&#146;s and its subsidiaries&#146; ability to permit liens or incur indebtedness, and restrictions on Unitil&#146;s ability to merge or consolidate with another entity or
	change its line of business. The affirmative and negative covenants under
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	33
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage36"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D262254D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	the Credit Facility shall apply to Unitil until the Credit Facility terminates and all amounts borrowed under the Credit Facility are paid in full (or with respect to letters of credit, they are
	cash collateralized). The only financial covenant in the Credit Facility provides that Unitil&#146;s Funded Debt to Capitalization (as each term is defined in the Credit Facility) cannot exceed 65%, tested on a quarterly basis. At December&nbsp;31,
	2016 and December&nbsp;31, 2015, the Company was in compliance with the covenants contained in the Credit Facility in effect on that date.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Company and its subsidiaries are currently in compliance with all such covenants in these debt instruments.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	DIVIDENDS
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-6PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Unitil&#146;s annual common dividend was $1.42 per common
	share in 2016, $1.40 per common share in 2015, and $1.38 per share in 2014. Unitil&#146;s dividend policy is reviewed periodically by the Board of Directors. Unitil has maintained an unbroken record of quarterly dividend payments since trading began
	in Unitil&#146;s common stock. At its January 2017 meeting, the Unitil Corporation Board of Directors declared a quarterly dividend on the Company&#146;s common stock of $0.36 per share, an increase of $0.005 per share on a quarterly basis,
	resulting in an increase in the effective annual dividend rate to $1.44 from $1.42. The amount and timing of all dividend payments are subject to the discretion of the Board of Directors and will depend upon business conditions, results of
	operations, financial conditions and other factors. In addition, the ability of the Company&#146;s subsidiaries to pay dividends or make distributions to Unitil, and, therefore, Unitil&#146;s ability to pay dividends, depends on, among other things:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-6PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	the actual and projected earnings and cash flow, capital requirements and general financial condition of the Company&#146;s subsidiaries;
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-6PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

	&nbsp;

</TD>

<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>

<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">

</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">

	subsidiaries;
</FONT>

</TD>

</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-6PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">

</FONT>

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	the restrictions on the payment of dividends contained in the existing loan agreements of the Company&#146;s subsidiaries and that may be contained in
	future debt agreements of the Company&#146;s subsidiaries, if any; and
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-6PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
